Authors: Chao Ge Wang, Josef Vlasák, Yu Cheng Dai
Title:
Multi-gene phylogeny and taxonomy of Physisporinus
(Polyporales, Basidiomycota)
Keywords:
Meripilaceae, Multi-marker analyses, polypore, taxonomy,
wood-decaying fungi
Abstract:
Phylogenetic and morphological analyses on Physisporinus
are carried out. The genus is characterized by annual to perennial,
resupintae, effused-reflexed to distinctly pileate or stipitate
basidiomata which are soft, ceraceous, corky or leathery when fresh,
become fragile, resinous, hard corky to woody hard when dry; fresh pores
become bloody red, brownish or unchanged when bruised; a monomitic
hyphal structure, thin- to thick-walled generative hyphae with simple
septa, hyphoid cystidia present in most species, hyaline, thin-walled,
ellipsoid, ovoid, subglobose to globose basidiospores and causing a
white rot. The studied specimens are mainly from Asia, Europe, and North
and Central America. Phylogenies on species of the genus are
reconstructed with multiple loci DNA sequences including the internal
transcribed spacer regions (ITS), the large subunit (nLSU) and the small
subunit (nSSU) of nuclear ribosomal RNA gene, the small subunit of
mitochondrial rRNA gene (mtSSU), the translation elongation factor 1-α
gene (TEF1) and the second subunit of RNA polymerase II (RPB2). The
results demonstrate that Physisporinus is monophyletic and belongs to
Meripilaceae in the residual polyporoid clade. One new genus,
Fuscorigidoporus, is established with two new species, F. costaricanus,
F. pericinus, and one combination F. hypobrunneus. 15 new species in
Physisporinus are described and illustrated, and Rigidoporus biokoensis
and Meripilus giganteus are proposed to combine into Physisporinus. An
identification key to accepted species of Physisporinus is
provided.
